name: Asparagus, Shrimp and Egg Drop Soup
description: To cook in advance, partially cover the pot after simmering the asparagus, let things cool, then keep at room temperature up to several hours, or refrigerate up to 2 days (return the soup to room temperature before proceeding). Then reheat to add the shrimp and finish the soup.
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon canola or other neutral oil
1/3 cup thinly sliced shallot or yellow onion
4 cups homemade chicken stock or low-sodium chicken broth
3 slices unpeeled ginger (each as thick as a bean sprout, lightly smacked with the broad side of a knife)
12-14 ounces asparagus (woody ends discarded, and cut on the diagonal into 1 1/4-inch-long pieces)
6 ounces jumbo or extra-larger shell-on shrimp (peeled, deveined, and cut into thumbnail-size nuggets)
2 1/2 tablespoons potato starch or cornstarch dissolved in 2 1/2 tablespoons stock or water

recipeInstructions.text: In a 3 to 4-quart saucepan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add the shallot (or onioand cook, stirring, 2 to 3 minutes, until soft. Add the stock, water, and ginger. Bring to a boil over high heat.
recipeInstructions.name: In a 3 to 4-quart saucepan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add the shallot (or onioand cook, stirring, 2 to 3 minutes, until soft. Add the stock, water, and ginger. Bring to a boil over high heat.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the asparagus, then adjust the heat to simmer, uncovered, for 15 minutes. For the most flavor, deliberately overcook the asparagus to a very tender texture and olive-green color; it won’t look cheery but will taste good. Discard the ginger.

recipeInstructions.text: To finish, return the soup to a simmer over medium heat. Add the shrimp and let cook until pink, about 1 minute. Lightly season with salt. Beat the egg and yolk with the fish sauce and black pepper; set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Give the starch mixture a stir and slowly pour it into the soup with one hand as you stir the soup with the other. You may not need the entire amount to thicken and create a thick silky texture. Continue stirring for about 30 seconds, or until the soup is thickened. Turn off the heat.

You may not need the entire amount to thicken and create a thick silky texture. Continue stirring for about 30 seconds, or until the soup is thickened. Turn off the heat.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the beaten egg onto the soup in a wide circle, then stir gently to break it up into chiffonlike pieces. Taste and season with extra salt as needed. Partially cover and let rest for 5 to 10 minutes to further develop good flavor. Ladle into individual bowls and serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
Made this according to your recipe except that I only had tiny "salad shrimp," so I added a small can of crabmeat. The flavor was a little, um, thin. So I added 1 pinch sugar, then, reluctantly, 1 pinch of msg.. I guess this makes it adaptable to canned ingredients. Anyway, it was delicious!
Thank you for highlighting potato starch! Corn starch is useful & cheap, but it always tastes a little metallic to me. Potato starch is all over Nordic cooking (hard to grow corn in Finland, where my people came from!) Also, it was Julia Child's secret to keep a vinaigrette from separating. I like the Swan brand best. Ingebretsen's here in Minneapolis sells it by mail if you can't find it.

This brings back so many memories! My mom used to make the version with canned asparagus (sometimes with white asparagus, if it was available) and crab meat. My siblings and I revolted when she made a version with fresh asparagus but my tastes have certainly changed. It's one of my favorite soups but you seldom see it on Vietnamese restaurant menus... so I guess this means I will need to make your version at home!
